entry.content:
Something very personal about my journey in acoustics.

‰∏Ä‰∫õÊµÅÊ∞¥Ë¥¶Ôºå‰∏Ä‰∫õÁ¢éÁ¢éÂøµ„ÄÇ

Language: English | ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá

Origin

My interest in acoustics began with a TED talk I watched during middle or high school (couldn‚Äôt find the browsing history, but I guess it was around Grade 10). In this talk, a creative technologist introduced how sound can be visualized by vibrating a medium such as sand and water. The demo looked so cool and visually appealing. The term ‚Äúcymatics‚Äù was new to me, and it sparked my curiosity to delve deeper into the world of acoustics.

Evan Grant: Making sound visible through cymatics

  • About Evan Grant: Why you should listen, TED profile.

Searching

At some point, when I was thinking about what major to study, I began searching for programs related to cymatics and acoustics. I could only check my emails to track my inquiries. Due to personal reasons, I decided to pursue my undergraduate studies in Canada. In November 2016, I emailed a university but didn‚Äôt mention acoustics, so I‚Äôm unsure if that was related. The first email I found mentioning acoustics was sent in March 2017. It looks quite naive in hindsight‚Ä¶ üòÇ

I sent inquiries to various universities, companies (like HEAD acoustics, ABD engineering), and organizations (like CAA, IOA of CAS). Fortunately, many of them replied, with some providing detailed explanations and forwarding my queries to others. I felt so grateful for their help. I might not have remembered these experiences if I hadn‚Äôt reviewed my emails. I also sent some DMs on zhihu.com and received responses, which was helpful.

I wanted to study acoustics at the undergraduate level, but I could not find a specific program in Canada. There was one at the University of Sherbrooke, but since I don‚Äôt speak French, I could not apply. Based on my search and the feedback I received, I decided to apply for mechanical engineering and physics, and eventually chose to study physics.

Learning

I started my undergraduate studies in September 2018. I somehow found the MAT (Musical Applications of Technology) and MST (Musical Science & Technology) minor programs. According to my email records, I inquired about relevant courses in December 2018. And in October 2019, a master student (the mentor I had in our physics program) told me I might be interested in the CIRMMT center at our school. Then in February 2020, I applied for the MAT and was convinced to take MST instead. I got accepted. Although not all courses or assignments captured my interest, overall, it was a very good program. The professors were very dedicated.

Also in February 2020, through the Job Shadowing Program, I connected with an alumnus working at a local acoustical consulting firm. I visited him and his workplace. He holds a PhD in Mechanical Engineering, and most of his colleagues were PhDs, some Masters, and an undergraduate intern. Through communication with him and his colleagues, I was impressed by their work, their passion, and their expertise. I might have thought: I hope I can be one of them. Perhaps it was around this time I realized I needed to pursue further studies.

Just like how I applied for undergraduate programs in high school, I continued searching for master‚Äôs programs in my third or fourth year. I consulted some of my professors and even reached out to an expert (also an alumnus) on LinkedIn. I found there are many programs in Europe (relatively). Plus, due to another personal interest, I decided to move to Sweden to study Sound and Vibration.

Since arriving in Sweden, I‚Äôve felt very fortunate. All the courses align with my interests, and everyone is incredibly friendly ‚Äî the professors, classmates, and alumni. We support each other like a big family. Sometimes I wonder whether I enjoy physics and acoustics or just the company of the wonderful people I‚Äôve met. I think it‚Äôs a bit of both.

Looking Back & Future

When people ask me why I study physics or acoustics, I often say it‚Äôs because of its interdisciplinary nature. To be honest, I don‚Äôt have a clear answer. Perhaps it was because I was deeply attracted by the beauty of sound visualization from that TED talk video, or maybe it was not a common choice, or I didn‚Äôt have the time to explore the beauty of other subjects. Sound is so closely related to our daily lives, and we experience it consciously and unconsciously every day. I‚Äôve asked this question to my classmates as well. Some people say it sounds cool to study physics, some say they don‚Äôt like other subjects, and most of them cite personal interest and passion. If not for proactive learning, many people might not even be aware of the existence of acoustics as a subject.

Fundamentally, acoustics is a subset of physics and can be applied in various fields like engineering, psychology, music, and many more. If I could start over, would I still choose to study physics and acoustics? For now, I think so. I do like other subjects like liberal arts, but I cannot imagine myself studying them day after day or making a living out of it. (But, if I had unlimited time and resources, I would love to learn more about all different subjects.) I appreciate writers and artists and admire those who excel in their fields, but I know I am not one of them.

I remember writing in some of my master‚Äôs program application statements about how scholars like Thomas Rossing helped in the development of the Hang¬Æ by contributing to the tuning techniques (ref: Life-changing, a chimera or just a drum?), a musical instrument, that allows us to hear such extraordinary sounds. This synergy between art and science fascinates me. Acoustics is such a field. It spans a wide range of applications. It is simple yet complex. It is ancient yet innovative. As science and technology advance and as people pay more attention to their sensory experiences and seek a sustainable environment, I believe research in acoustics will continue to flourish. I have only scratched the surface, and there is so much more to explore.

Language: English | ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá

2016 - First Impression

It all began with a TV series - yes, I enjoy watching TV üòÑ. In the summer of 2016, I was captivated by a unique ‚Äúwok-like‚Äù musical instrument that appeared in To Be a Better Man. It sounded so beautiful, and I had never seen anything like it. I started searching online to figure out what it was. After reading some Q&A posts, I discovered that the instrument is called Hang¬Æ, from Switzerland. Due to copyright issues, other similar instruments are referred to as Handpan. I can‚Äôt remember exactly how I stopped searching, but it definitely planted a seed in my mind.

PANArt - Hang¬Æ Sculpture

PANArt Hang documentary 2006: HANG - a discreet revolution

Manu Delago - Hang solo (Mono Desire)

2021 - Revisit

Life goes on, and time flies. Around January 2021, while staying at home during the pandemic, I found myself watching videos of handpan performances again. This time, I delved deeper into it ‚Äî I emailed PANArt, the creators of the Hang¬Æ. Unfortunately, ‚Äúdue to the pandemic and the restrictions‚Äù, I couldn‚Äôt visit them in Switzerland, so I joined a WeChat group for handpan enthusiasts in China. I received some advice but eventually decided to set the idea aside.

Later on, I thought about handpan from time to time, either passively or spontaneously. While pursuing a minor in Musical Science and Technology, I incorporated Handpan-related elements into the final projects for MUMT 306 - Fall 2021 and MUMT 307 - Winter 2022. Although working with handpan wasn‚Äôt my original intent ‚Äî I prefer experiencing live music from real instruments ‚Äî it still provided some inspiration.

Solo Hang Drum in a Tunnel | Daniel Waples - Hang in Balance | London - England [HD]

Hang Massive - Once Again - 2011 ( hang drum duo ) ( HD )

2022 - First Touch

Then I came to Europe. To some extent, it was because of Hang¬Æ and handpan. Soon after I arrived, I found a local handpan maker. I was so excited to see a handpan in real life! I immediately ordered one from him and bought a course book from China as well. Unfortunately, the production did not proceed as planned.

A handpan made by Franzen Instruments.


Marcel Hutter - Granit

Sam Maher - New York Handpan 01

Sam Maher - New York Handpan 02

2023 - Acquired

I searched online and ordered one from Yatao. With excitement and anxiety, I received the package! It was bigger than I expected, and to be honest, the colour was not my favourite. But it sounds good, which is enough. I finally owned a handpan and could start playing it!

The package I received on February 2, 2023.

Unboxing.

The handpan on a stand.


Sam Maher & Manu Delago - Whitechapel | A Take Away Show

Kate Stone | ‚ÄúUrban‚Äù official video | Opsilon Handpan

Handpan Guitarviola | Yuki Koshimoto Fugaku Yohei |

2024 - Learning

Most of the time, I play my handpan casually, whenever I feel like it, rather than practice deliberately. One day, I somehow noticed that Manu Delago would be performing in Vienna, Austria. I immediately decided to buy a ticket and go see the concert!

(Side note: Initially, I confused the concert venue with the Golden Hall, which made me even more excited to visit Vienna. Later, I found out from a friend that the concert was actually at a different venue - I had mixed up the Musikverein and Konzerthaus. I also discovered that Lang Lang was going to perform at the Golden Hall on the same day as Manu‚Äôs concert. I really wish I had a clone to attend both concerts!)

During the intermission, I went to the front of the stage to look at the handpans Manu was playing and started a conversation with an audience member standing next to me. I asked him what Manu was saying during the performance (as I don‚Äôt understand German), and we ended up talking about Manu, handpan, and ourselves. He introduced himself as Andy, a composer, teacher, and handpan player. He invited me to his studio for a lesson. Everything was so unexpectedly wonderful!

Recently (at the end of June), while volunteering at a conference, I heard the sound of a handpan in the Immersive Audio room. Even before the video appeared, I instantly recognized the sound of the handpan due to its unique and beautiful tone. It was a live performance by Martin K√§lberer mixed by Stefan Bock.

The concert >>Between Us<< on May 29, 2024.


Anoushka Shankar & Manu Delago with Metropole Orkest Strings - Live at Le Guess Who?

entry.title: My First Blog Post ÊàëÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢ÊñáÁ´†
entry.content:
Language: English | ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá

I‚Äôve wanted to build my own website for a long time, a place to gather my experiences, thoughts, and life moments. A space where I can document the places I‚Äôve been, the photos I‚Äôve taken, the people I‚Äôve met, and the things I‚Äôve encountered. Think of it as a digital diary. But I never started. Now isn‚Äôt the best time to begin either, as I have more important things to do. Yet, I don‚Äôt feel like doing them. So here I am.

I don‚Äôt want to reveal too much about my personal life, but perhaps we are all already ‚Äúnaked‚Äù in this digital world. It‚Äôs challenging to focus solely on myself without mentioning family, friends, or others. I am well aware of my limited knowledge and abilities. I don‚Äôt know who, other than myself, would read or care about this. But even if it‚Äôs just for me, that‚Äôs enough.

I‚Äôve forgotten many childhood experiences and can‚Äôt recall them. Without words, photos, videos, or memories, how can we bring back the past? I have no idea. Maybe I just want to leave something behind. This public website is a beginning; I hope it is not the end.
